This is a OpenScad LIBRARY :)

Photo are given as example. Download all files in a same folder, and open "
CrownGearV7.main.scad" to see and change the code of given example.

Step 1 :
function "rouePrincipale" (main gear in french) allow to set parameter of the main gear

Step 2:
function "roueAccordee" (paired gear in french) calculate for you the parameter of a paired gear.

Step 3 :
function "dessinRouePrincipale" ( draw main gear in french ) draw the main gear with the given gear parameter and color

Step 4 :
function roueEnPosition("roue2-1","orange" , roue1Prm, roue2Prm, 30); (gear in place in french) draw the paired gear with given name, parameters of main and paired gear ) and the position (angle) on main gear. The name is important, it is user un console to explain the calculation of it parameters

Step X:
The function "fy" defined in "CrownGearV7.param.scad" is the draw of one tooth. The "curve". Change this function as you wish. It applies to all gear created.

Problem Statement:
Recent analysis by the Staples finance department has concluded that sales for desktop
organization products have declined in recent years. The company would like to ramp up their profits in
this area by enhancing the aesthetic nature of these products.
Your group of three has been hired to design a set of theme-based organizational products. Your
team will design a set of office supplies that are tied together with a common theme. You must be able to
justify the theme that connects the products together. The idea is that the customer will not want to buy
just one; they will want to buy the whole set. OPTIONS:
 Pencil holder that can securely hold at least 5 pencils
 Expo marker holder than can securely hold at least 4 markers
 Pen holder that can securely hold at least 5 pens
 Tape dispenser that will hold and cut a roll of scotch tape
 Anything you can get approved by your project manager! Constraints:
You will be constructing an actual size model of your product in Solidworks
It should be cool to look at and unique - a conversation starter. An individual walking by would do
a double take to more closely examine the amazingly interesting item you’ve created.
There should be a theme that ties the products together
It should have multiple extrusions for detail
It should contain examples of ALL THREE main features: revolve, sweep, loft
It takes advantage of the following: circular pattern, linear pattern, mirror
It takes advantage of at least one of the following: filleting, chamfering
Each piece should fit within a 10cm x 10 cm x 10cm cube
Should be 3D printable

Valentine Tealight is the first in a new concept I am trying. You print a thin flexible sheet that is rolled into a cylinder and help in place by a groove in the base and lid. The technique allows for potentially more detail in on the sides since it can be printed without supports. The sheet can also be much thinner that if it were printed upright.

I've tried this in PETG. I'm not sure it will work in PLA but maybe if the sheet is printed thin enough.

I would suggest printing the sheet first then measuring it's actual thickness. Mine printed out with an actual thickness of 0.85mm so I set the groove value to 1.00mm and this worked for me. You may need to experiment a bit.

Depending on your printer, you may need to print the sheet diagonally.

Feel free to try your own designs.

More to come!

Notes:

Differents Infill percentages change weigh, but not much stability. Printed with hexagonal pattern but not needed, if 3 or more faces are set for external face distance/lenth.

I used Simplify3D to diference 10% of model at 20% infill, then up to 15% with 4 face lines (due fragil tail in some models) with 8% infill and up 100% (the rest of the model) using 8% infill and 3 face lines. It's not useful, but I decided to do it and it works, I spend more time slicing.

Something important in the beard: too much supports there will cause bad quality on the external face, be polite! And some supports under the ears could be usefull to make them fix, but not needed if model is not scaled.

Some versions need to cut tail-cover if you prefer without them, you will see it when you printed, not a problem, BUT NEVER CUT THE TAIL! IT IS A HUGE PAIN FOR THEM (I'm talking about real dogs, hehehe)

Also remove supports if you use them.

title: Ford Mondeo Mk4 Phone holder for OnePlus 3T

description.text:
I'm not a professional 3d modeler, but I'm an engineer designing mechanical stuff in Inventor and Fusion 360, so forgive me if some surfaces in the models are a littlebit odd. This is my first upload to Thingiverse.

After buying and using several phone holders for my OnePlus 3T for use in my car (Ford Mondeo Mk4), which all failed, I decided I'd try designing one specifically for my car.

First I made some pictures of the dashboard and the left 'triangular' cover of the car's console, which I imported in Fusion as a canvas. From there I started the reversed engineering process of that coverplate. After printing and testing/fitting two physical models I got the right dimensions so that the coverplate snaps into place correctly. After that the modelling of the phoneholder started. For that I downloaded a STEP file of the OnePlus 3T from GrabCAD, but that model wasn't accurate. So I reverse-Engineered my own phone by taking pictures of the phone from different angles and used them in Fusion 360 to model the phone and use this model to design the holder. After three test-prints the model was accurate enough to snug-fit the phone into.

In this post you'll find four STL's:

  • Ford Mondeo MK4 Console Cover Left.stl
    This is a plain coverplate for the Mondeo MK4, which can be used for all purposes, like a replacement cover, or to use as a template for other phoneholders or accessories. I think when you mirror this part, you can use it for the right coverplate of the console
  • OnePlus 3T Body.stl
    This is a simple model of the OnePlus 3T. It has no camera-bump or side buttons, it was used merely for the phone holder to fit the cross section of the phone.
  • Ford Mondeo MK4 Console Cover With hinge for Phone holder.stl
    This is the coverplate with the hinge.
  • OnePlus 3T Phone Holder With Hinge.stl
    This is the actual OnePlus 3T phone holder with hinge.

The last two parts can be joined by means of a Hex socket screw M4x25 and a standard M4 nut.

Thanks anyone for using my models. Please leave some comments and thumbs-up if these models helped you.

Gearbox mounting bracket is drop in, friction fit, no fasteners required. Will require modification of the stock trigger group mounting bracket to allow gearbox clearance.

Search: arduino smart car for the 130 motor gearbox. Should run about $2 per gearbox/motor; prices will vary widely, but these are available for less than $2. Swap motor for 130 motor of choice to set cyclical rate. Higher torque rated motors will ensure more reliable feed and reduce odds of jams.

Functionally, this kit works just like the AutoStryfe mod kit.

Test video link follows. Wiring guide to be released. This blaster can be wired using the AutoStryfe wiring guide, but ONLY without the lights and sound circuitry. Attempting to run any of the Hasbro Nerf Star Wars blasters with sound and lights on even a 2S LiPo battery will damage the sound and light circuitry.

Pronterfaceâ€™s webinterface is not ready for primetime just yet (lacking a lot of necessary features) . But give it a little time and experiment on your own, you might just amaze yourself! If you've got any tips, errors or additions, please let me know! (if you like, use the attached logo for your SD-card) My endgoal is to make either a distributable image or a script that does all this work on its own, but i'm a long way from getting there. Please help if you can! Requirements Raspberry Pi
4gb SDcard (class 4 or up)
Regular PC (WinMacLin)
Internet connection to PC and to Pi board
Micro USB cable for power and a USB cable to your 3d printer
USB keyboard/mouse
HDMI enabled screen (TV will do fine) First things first. We need to download a Raspbian image to the SDcard. Get the image at http://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads and follow the guide at http://elinux.org/RPi_Easy_SD_Card_Setup When the SDcard is complete, connect the Pi to your HDMI screen, network, keyboard, SDcard and last: power. After a short wait you should get the configuration menu. Check your settings and most importantly: enable SSH connections! Also use the SD card partition resizer. Reboot after youâ€™ve saved your settings by using â€˜sudo rebootâ€™ Connect to your Pi using SSH, login as pi/raspberry. Alternatively, if you are sitting comfortably at your Pi-keyboard, just use that. After login, itâ€™s time to do some updates: sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get upgrade This will take a little while. After that, itâ€™s wise to reboot (sudo reboot) and reconnect a minute or so later. Now we will install a lot of dependencies and useful tools. This will take some time. sudo apt-get install python python-dev python-serial python-wxgtk2.8 python-pygletÂ git-core The system will ask you if itâ€™s okay to download and use diskspace. Sure it is.
Now weâ€™ve got a complete set of Python tools and the Git system, which will download Pronterface for us! Weâ€™ll need CherryPy for the web-server part. wget download.cherrypy.org/cherrypy/3.2.0rc1/CherryPy-3.2.0rc1.tar.gz
tar -xf CherryPy-3.2.0rc1.tar.gz
cd CherryPy-3.2.0rc1/
sudo python setup.py install To test CherryPy you can do the following cd cherrypy/tutorial
pico tutorial.conf edit the IP adress to the Piâ€™s adress, press control+O (writeout, press enter) and control+X (exit) python tut01_helloworld.py Use a browser on any computer in the network, visit: Piâ€™s IP adress:8080 You should get a hello world. Press control+C afterwards to exit CherryPyâ€™s demo.
Great stuff! Now everything is ready for Pronterface! cd /home/pi
git clone git://github.com/kliment/Printrun.git This will download the latest version of Pronterface/Printrun. But for the webinterface we need the experimental branch: cd Printrun
git checkout -b experimental origin/experimental You can check and change the settings for the Webinterface using Pico: pico http.config (change it to your IP adress!)
pico auth.config But first we need to edit Pronterface to enable the webinterface: pico pronterface.py Find the line â€˜webavail = Falseâ€™ and change it to â€˜Trueâ€™. Save and exit. At this point you can run pronterface.py from the GUI (using Python) and your webinterface will be waiting for you! To enable STL slicing, you can install Skeinforge by typing sudo apt-get install skeinforge which will install skeinforge to /usr/share/skeinforge. Slic3r should work, but i havenâ€™t got it operational just yet (a lot of dependencies and stuff required).

title: Geeetech I3 Pro C  Z Endstop holder with Adjustment

description.text:
This is an adjustable holder for the GEEETECH I3 PRO C Z Endstop. It fits the Acryilc Version with the flange behind the left Z Rod, as a post for the Endstop.

The original way with the screw is just a laugh, i tried some designs but was not satisfied.

As need a few of these..for a public highshool project.. i designed this one .

I included all sources , so redesign for other printers should be easy.

The thumbwheel is derived from :
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225188
and modified for this project

Notes:

print it relatively stiff , imade some in PLA some in ABS . Make sure orientation of fixed part and actuator is correct.. Cura 3.1.0 mirrored them here!

After Print fit 2 M3 and 1 M4 Nut. in fixed Part. Screw ( M4 x 50 --- 70 ) needs 2 M4 Nuts.
You need 2 M3 Screws about 30 to 40 mm long. Take HEX Versions to have a small head . Use 2 (10 - 15 by 4.5 by 1) Coils..maybe salvaged from ballpens .

Fix it to the original Z-Endstop flange with 2 M3 Screws.. M3 x 20 should fit

Make sure the Endstop holder moves freely but still fixed within the flanges.. I sanded them and smoothent them ( ABS ) . If you can afford use Screws with NO Thread at the upper 15mm ...they make it move easier. Otherwise, you can smear glue into the Threads to make them move smooth against the coils .

You can paint the thumbwheel marks . Each mark means 0.1 mm Movement of the Switch.

When inserting the original Endstop..(no glue etc. needed.).. remove the rubber from the cable connectors and REMOVE or bend flat, the middle contact of the switch. Guide the cables thru both the fixed and moving part slots .

The HOLE in the middle of the moving parts lower side must be refined so the M4 nut does not stick in it..nor should it move tooo freely. Use a file or 4.2 mm drill or the nut itself to open it slightly. Alternatively remove 2 mm of thread from the 4mm bolts tip.

print_settings.Notes:: Works well with many filament colors, but it looks brighter with white filament.

description.text:
This version is similar to my previous one titled "Lithophane Frame Curved". It also uses lithophanes made from square aspect pictures. This frame is designed for lithophanes of size 100mm by 100mm by 3mm.
In my experience, if everything is printed with white filament, then the walls will reflect the light from a strip of 6 white LED's very well and it will light up the box in a nice uniform way. I usually place the LED strip flat on the bottom facing up.
In my examples here I used 2 strips, one whit and one blue. In my next version I plan on adding an extra box for a circuit to drive RGB LED's.
The hole near the bottom is 8.5 mm in diameter for a common 12V DC power adapter cord to power the LED strip.
If you plan on adding text to the top cover, you can do either hollow text like I did or it can be solid raised text. I personally like the text to be on the bottom side of the cover because I use Cura 14.07 most of the time. But with better settings or better slicer software you could probably achieve very good results printing text on the top side. This will give you a sharper, crisper text easier to see from a distance.
In my examples I used 3D Solutech Teal color filament. I like this color because in low light situations it looks blue when LED's are off and it looks green when it's on.

description.text:
After trying some other designs i found most fit other versions of the printer. I needed it or the Acrylic PRO3 C Dual Extruder Version. This one moves X Axis Holder down very deep so that most designs with thick body do not fit.

It uses the original brass nut and 4 M3 x 6 screws. I use the additional washer and anoterh washer i make from 1 MM thick PTFE Foil between the printed washer and the X Mount. This gives smoooooth movement. You can see what you may have to fill this 2-3 mm.GAP for best movement. This is the magic in these Z-X decouplers.

Be sure the fork moves smoothly but not too wobbly along the smooth 8mm Rod

Freecad files included ( FC 0.17 !)
File or sand the Fork for best fit.

description.text:
I have to admit that I am a fanboy of smart home stuff at home. Particularly I like the remote control sockets from Osram because they work with the Hue light bulbs from Phillips (see http://geni.us/YsiW).
This is the right Osram smart + socket: http://geni.us/zwqVBA

But from my point of view, they have a big design failure. The socket can be switched on and off with very low pressure. If you have small children or pets at home, or if you want to prevent accidental switch-on you can use this small protection plate.

I have designed it for the EU Socket. If it's needed, I try to customize it also for other regions. Please send me a message if you need it for a different type.

title: Mad Manor of Astabar - Moon Skulls

description.text:
I'm DM'ing a run of Mad Manor of Astabar, which hinges on collecting 8x human skulls etched with the symbol of the 8x moon phases. I thought it'd be fun if my players could actually hold and examine the skulls, so designed the moon symbols & imprinted 'em into scaled-down versions of DanLuc's human skull.

References:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:224912
http://www.drivethrurpg.com/product/138937/The-Mad-Manor-of-Astabar

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Here's how I printed it:
Print surface: AnyCubic Ultrabase, heated to 80C for the whole print.
Filament: 3D Solutech Natural-color 1.75mm PLA
Extrusion temp: 220C first layer, 210C for the rest
Slicer: Simplify3D
Infill: 5%, fast-honeycomb
Cooling: 0% first layer, 80% at layer 2 and above
Supports x-distance: 0.2mm
Supports y-spacing: 1 layer above, 1 layer below

I was a little amazed that it worked okay with only 5% infill, but I'd recommend going with more - the bottom/internal edges of the symbols would really benefit from some infill to rest upon. I had a couple small gaps within the symbols due to lack of internal support (ie: infill). I printed all 8x skulls at once, as a single process (ie: layer-by-layer, not model-by-model), and it took about 14 hours start to finish. So, estimate about 2 hours per skull.

Support came away without too much trouble, but the teeth were kinda hit-or-miss. I lost a lot of teeth while removing the support. That being said, I don't really care - it just looks the skulls look less obviously-identical. Each one's missing a different random combination of teeth.

Aside: I've found that 3D Solutech filaments tolerate way higher temps than you'd expect of PLA. Most notably, at anything less than 70C, the PLA wouldn't stick to the Ultrabase at all. At 80C it sticks like glue, and completely releases itself as the plate cools to ~30C.

title: AX2 2 speed gearbox cover + servo mount

description.text:
I have bought AX2 2-speed gearbox for my Axial SCX10. I found out that holes of original Axial gerbox cover does not line up with mouting holes on AX2. And mount for 50g servo is to long for my Proline Chevrolet Silverado body. I think that problem will be common for Honcho, Ford F150 or similar bodies. So I designed cover that will fit and servo mount for 9g servo. Servo mount is bigger than it should be but I am using it as a platform for mounting my ESC. Cover itself also could be bit slimmed but I keep it on safe side so there should be no contact between gears and wall.

I have printed it from clear PETG on my Anet A8 with 0,5mm jet.I am still tuning setting for PETG but after little bit it fits nicely under motor mount.

You will need 6x screw M3x8, 3x M3 nut and 2x screw M3x25. These two replace 2x M3x20 that hold motor mount on gearbox and will be short after you put cover base under motor mount. You will probably need them cut to M3x22. But with stock clutch mount it could be OK. I am using solid mount that is closer to gearbox. So I had to cut them to correct lenght.

author: fronzjr

description.text: Happy Birthday Day Heart Decoration

My wife takes a bunch of different vitamins every day. She like to sort them into little plastic bags for the morning and evening so they are easily available and she can take these "vita-packs" with her when she travels. Sorting and getting the vitamins into those little bags was a total pain so I created a sorter/dispenser to make it easier. You simply place the pills into the slots and then rotate the spindle while holding a bag under the dispenser.

I have included a short and tall version of the spool but you can easily create any spool height needed. The design still has some bugs as the pills sometimes get stick in the dispenser (especially multiple gel-coated capsules) I just use a small rod to push them through.

The spindle rotates via a small ULN2003 5V stepper motor (you could also just rotate the spindle manually). I put in a simple Ardunio controller module to run the stepper motor using a touch switch on the left side.

The design is still a work in progress but it works so I am not sure if I will do another iteration.

title: Particulates Sensor Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Note: The white box is a stock junction box. It's not printed.

This is a frame for a luftdaten.info compatible particulates sensor.

The original sensor is housed in drain pipes, which is cheap, but also looks quite like that. ;-)

This construction uses an OBO Bettermann T60 junction box, which looks nicer, and is also UV resistant and IP66 water protected. All components are mounted on the printed frame and fixed inside the junction box. Two wind pipes at the bottom of the box allow air flow. A printed tunnel guides the inlet air to the sensor, so there is no need for a hose. Grilles in the wind pipes keep insects from crawling into the box.

A DHT22 temperature and humidity sensor is required for this construction. It is placed at the wall of the inlet air tunnel, so it is protected from rain, but still exposed to the outside air. There is a space for an optional BMP180 air pressure sensor.

Bauanleitung auf Deutsch (assembly instructions in German)

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Use a material that allows to drive in screws without cracking. Since the printed parts are mounted inside the junction box, the filament does not need to be UV resistant or particularly weatherproof. I have used PLA.

No ambient light should fall into the chamber of the particulates sensor. For this reason I recommend to use a dark filament, at least for the top frame part.

Do not use supports, as they may be difficult to remove after printing.

• Remove both plug-in seals from one side of the junction box. This will be the bottom side later.
  • Insert the USB cable through the left hole.
  • Put the base plate into the junction box and tighten it with 4x 3.5 x 12 mm screws. You can also use 3.0 x 12 mm screws if you don't have 3.5 mm screws at hand.
  • Cut open the two plug-in seals at 19-20 mm diameter, and use them to seal the junction box again.
  • Solder the sensors and sensor cables to the NodeMCU. Use shrinkable tubing for the pins of the DHT22 sensor. Check that the wiring is correct. Check again.
  • You should install the sensor firmware and run a test now. It will be more difficult once the sensor is assembled.
  • Fix the NodeMCU and the optional BMP180 sensor to their bolts, using 3.0 x 12 mm screws. Connect it to the USB cable.
  • Insert the DHT22 sensor into its place (see photo). It does not need to be fixed.
  • Place the upper plate in its position and tighten it with 2x 3.0 x 12 mm screws.
  • Connect the SDS011 cable to the sensor. You may need to cut away a little bit of the connector's plastic to make it fit into the junction box.
  • Put the SDS011 sensor to the top of the sandwich. Be careful when inserting the air inlet into the printed air tunnel. Tighten the sensor with 3x 3.0 x 12 mm screws.
  • That's it. You can close the junction box now.

Besides the printed parts, you need:

  • OBO Bettermann T60 junction box with plug-in seals
  • ILS-Nova PM Sensor SDS011
  • Lolin NodeMCU (make sure it's Lolin, other brands may not fit)
  • DHT 22 (temperature and humidity sensor)
  • 11 screws 3.0 x 12 mm
  • 4 screws 3.5 x 12 mm (if available, or four more 3.0 x 12mm)
  • Some ribbon cable
  • Some shrinkable tubing
  • USB cable with flat wire
  • USB power supply (a disused old USB charger will do, the sensor consumes less than 200 mA)

Optionally:

  • BMP180 (temperature and air pressure sensor)

title: Tevo Little Monster filament spool replacement with bearings

description.text:
This is a replacement spool holder for the Tevo Little Monster. It uses 6006 sealed bearings (I got them from Amazon for $11) and is adjustable for various width spools. It replaces the threaded rod that comes with the TLM as that is a bit over 30mm in diameter making these bearings not fit, plus the rod is about 20mm longer to accommodate wider filament spools.

The threaded rod is done in 2 pieces with a connector that joins them. The existing 30mm nuts on the TLM's rod go onto this threaded rod. The bearings go next to the filament spool with the bearing cover tapers facing in towards the spool.

It reduces the friction quite a bit on the spool allowing for the flying extruder to easily pull new filament off the roll.

remixed_from.title: Light Machine Gun for Scale Models

title: British Bren LMG and Boys ATR  (28mm scale)

description.text:
I was looking for a model to try to print accessory vehicle weaponry for 28mm AFVs. The commercial ones are of white metal and are often bent beyond recognition when you receive them or the plastic "bits" are often fragile; a bren gun barrel in real life was about 1.5" across, which works out to be just over 1 mm. in 1/56th scale... so the plastic weapons from Warlord sprues will often snap even when handled with care.
So I started with Zeta-Guns file, thickened it and added the magazine and barrel flare at the end of Bren's barrel.
I use the same model to make the Boys ATR; but made the magazine angular and barrel longer.
Please note these are not proportionally correct, but someone else playing bolt Action will be able to recognize - "oh, you've got a pintle Bren on that carrier", or recognize the Boys ATR poking out of the front glacis plate of your universal carrier. That is much better than saying "Oh that carrier is shooting at you; you can't see but it carries two bren guns.." The "Fog of War" defence may not work in the post-game debrief.

I made both the bren gun and the Boys ATR as "stand alones" - ideal for poking out the front of your carrier (or the Dingo Armoured Car I loaded a pic of); as well I made a pintle mount for you to put on the LRDG trucks, jeeps or the like.
NOTES on printing - please use both a brim and a raft; and use a very fine setting; these are tiny pieces and they will get messed up without a secure base on the build plate. if loading several onto one build, leave space between them; I found out the hard way in the initial test print.

You will also need to "trick" the Carvey's smart clamp with something that has the same Z thickness as the material in the vise, plus the thickness of the vise. We are working on a model for that, but several small blocks and shims could achieve this.

title: 120mm M829A3 APFSDS-T
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A 1/3rd Scale 120mm Armor Piercing, Fin Stabilized, Discarding Sabot - Tracer (APFSDS-T) round used by some NATO main battle tanks such as the M1 Abrams.

Print out 3x each of Sabot 1, Sabot 2 and Sabot 3. Requires some assembly (superglue), it helps to be an octopus... I used a piece of the penetrator to serve as a guide to ensure the sabot pieces lined up correctly while the glue dried. There is still a bigger gap between sabot petals than I would have liked, but it helped reduce some fitment issues.

A test print on a CR-10 came out satisfactorily, but it may require some light sanding and minor fitting. I tweaked the design very slightly after the test print to improve fitting, so if you encounter any issues let me know.

In the future I may add cavities in the sabot petals for magnets to help keep it together while it's not in the case. Enjoy!

title: Everest Gen7 Pro FPV Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount for attaching an FPV camera to your Everest Gen7 Pro. It requires mounting to the roll bar, and thus the removal of the windshield. I have included a mount for a Runcam Split, which should work with most standard FPV cameras on the market, and a mount for an All-in-one camera and video transmitter unit, such as https://www.getfpv.com/lumenier-aio-adjustable-mini-fpv-camera-0-25-50-200mw-vtx-w-clover-antenna.html

The camera mounts bolt onto the base with an M3 bolt. If you prefer a fixed camera, you can just tighten the bolt really well. If you want to have some pivot to your camera, you have multiple options. I recommend putting a couple M3 washers between the base and the camera mount, and then just getting the nut snug. For the motion, you can use the FPV_mount_Base.stl and use a pushrod approach as seen in the picture, or you can use either of the geared mounts and print the servo_gear.stl which will mount on a 9g servo.

I used a Y-splitter to combine my steering with the camera panning servo. If you take the geared approach, and use a y-splitter, you will need to reverse the motion of the servo by taking it apart and switching some wires around... there are many tutorials online. If you use a more than 2 channel radio, just use another channel to control your panning servo.

The mount base is held to the Pro roll cage using Zip-ties. For the Runcam Split, I mounted my processing board and video transmitter to the inside of the roof, and ran the antenna up through the spare tire.

Redcat parts on Thingiverse are released under the Creative Commons License Attribution- NonCommercial- ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0).

We want to share these parts with the world, and we want to inspire people to make and share their own parts for their vehicles.

In keeping with the non-commercial clause of this license, if you produce this part (FPV_mount_base.stl and associated camera mount parts) for others, you may not receive compensation in excess of $13 per part, plus your shipping costs. This number is calculated based on an average estimate of material cost and machine running costs.

title: WedgeBase
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I'm doing an electronics project that is requiring LED lighting and I wanted to make something that I could quickly replace an LED if I decided to. I had bought some LED replacement bulbs for my truck and they were the wedge base design so I thought that would work perfect for what I needed. I have a bunch of wedge base sockets so it all came together nicely. So I took one of them and after measuring them designed my own that could accept any type of incandescent or led lamp that had both power leads on the one end.

NOTE: For those that don't deal with LED's much. A standard LED runs on between 3 - 3.8 volts DC, if you plan on making replacement LED lamps for your car remember your car or truck runs on DC voltages ranging from 11.5 to 14.5 volts DC (some run on a 24 volt DC system), if you simply throw a regular LED in one of these and plug it in it will for sure burn out! You will need whats called a ballast resistor or "Drop" resistor to reduce the DC voltage down to the 3 volts DC (3-3.5 volts depending on the type of LED), you can do a Google search on how to figure out the right size resistor to use. Also LED's are polarity sensitive devices, if you make one and it doesn't light up when you apply power simply pull it out of the socket and turn it 180* and reinsert it.

Also I am not responsible for any damage to your electrical circuit or car/ truck electrical systems.

title: PSVR Aim Controller Mounting Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These mounting clips are designed for the Playstation VR Aim Controller.

I made them so that I could mount my Aim Controller under a cabinet surface where it would be hidden from plain view when stored and accessed when booting up my Playstation and plugging in my PSVR headset. It is also positioned to be easily charged using the PS4 USB port.

It is designed to be used with medium 3M Command Strips.

The clips shown in the pictures, and the ones I am using, are .085" thick. I have also provided .100" thick files in case you need more stiffness. Mine are made from ABSPlus and seem to hold the controller sufficiently.

The idea is to hold the controller toward the bottom portion, put the top cross member up against the top of your cabinet (or coffee table, etc), slide that into the back horizontal clips, and then swing the bottom part of the controller up into the vertical clip(s). In the picture I am using the first version of the vertical clip I designed. It works sufficiently but you have to pull the controller toward you just a bit for it to slide in. I attempted to correct this in the rev A version but I have not tested it as I don't have easy access to a 3D printer.

Description of parts:

  • clip_085_horiz - Horizontal clips used at the back. 0.085" Thick.
  • clip_085_vert - Vertical clip used at the front. 0.085" Thick.

  • clip_085_vert_A - Vertical clip rev A attempting to correct the above described design flaw. 0.085" Thick.

  • clip_100_horiz - Horizontal clips used at the back. 0.100" Thick.
  • clip_100_vert - Vertical clip used at the front. 0.100" Thick.
  • clip_100_vert_A - Vertical clip rev A attempting to correct the above described design flaw. 0.100" Thick.

Obviously these can be used in any configuration and combination you like. All vertical or all horizontal clips is an option.

Models are in inches.

You may want to sand and wipe down the surface that is mating with the command strip. I haven't done testing to see if it's a problem to not sand it. I'm sure it also depends on the material you use. Also make sure to sand any rough edges that may scratch your controller.

To ensure easy mounting:

  1. Apply the Command Strips to the clips (following command strip instructions). Leave wall side plastic on.
  2. Snap the clips onto the controller in the desired locations.
  3. Place the controller and clips down on a table "upside down" like the table is your mounting surface.
  4. Use scotch tape to prevent the clips from rotating during the mounting process.
  5. Remove wall side plastic strips and place controller in your desired location. Press gently.
  6. Gently remove the controller from the clips.
  7. Press firmly on each command clip for at least the recommended 10 seconds to ensure adhesion.

description.text:
This is an assistive device designed to help a person with a transradial amputation grip a handle.It was designed by members of eNable Lowell, an on-campus group at the University of Massachusetts Lowell that designs and distributes 3D printed assistive devices to people with limb differences.

Note: The handle picture is 1 inch in diameter. You may scale the handle holder and grips to fit different size handles.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The handle holder should be printed with supports.

The pictured grips are printed with FILAMENTS.CA Flexible PLA filament.

Assembly

Sand any rough edges and remove support material.
Insert grips into handle holder, sanding or filing as necessary for a snug fit.
Cut and apply polyurethane foam to inside of gauntlet.
Use a soldering iron to heat up the inserts and push them into the gauntlet. Make sure the inserts are level with the top surface of the gauntlet. Let them cool before threading in screws.
Install rubber rod in flex adaptor and handle holder.
Use a 3mm drill bit to drill through the rubber on both the flex adaptor and handle holder, using the printed holes as a guide.
Pass an M3 screw through the hole in the rubber, and use a nut to secure the rubber rod in the flex adaptor and the handle holder.
Mount flex adaptor to gauntlet.
Pass velcro straps through side slots.
Push handle through handle holder device.

Hardware

3x M3 Heat Set Inserts
2x M3 Nuts
5x M3 Socket head Cap Screws
Rubber Rod
Polyurethane Foam w/ adhesive backing
Velcro Straps
(All materials can be purchased from McMaster-Carr or Amazon)

description.text:
Updated: 5 Feb 2018: Uploaded the beta of Version 2.0, with a new-clip together part set and revised document file. I recommend it over the original.

Updated: 08 Feb 2018: removed original files, please use the V2 files.

This is a set of parts to create a wind direction and speed sensor suitable for use as a hobby or club (sailing/flying) weather station in conjunction with a controller and either local display or web-connect software.

There are no mechanical switches in the design. Sensing is done by magnetic detection via Hall sensors, so the bearings (skateboard/fidget spinner type) are the only parts subject to wear. Note that the quality of the bearings is paramount if you want to achieve any sort of accuracy or linearity in the wind speed readings! The wind direction sensor is capable of very high accuracy/repeatability within a few degrees if well aligned.

A handful of additional electronic parts and the bearings are required to complete the project. Parts may be built on a small 3D printer, and the unit is very modular.

The additional parts required are:
A length (10cm) of 7mm fibreglass pole - scrap from a tent pole will do or an arrow.
Two Hall sensors, a couple of tiny magnets (available on eBay), 5mm stainless steel bolts, some skateboard/fidget spinner bearings, grommets, lead fishing weights (for the vane counterweight), a bit of 40mm PVC pressure pipe as the body, screws and some cable.
If you can't get 40mm Cat 12 PVC pipe, you can always 3D print an equivalent hollow cylinder, of course.

The full parts list is in the documentation file (DOCX) along with the circuit and code for an Arduino hookup to test and calibrate the unit.

EvoBot: an open source liquid handling robot

This is a general purpose liquid handling robot that is based on a modular design. Syringe modules (or other modules) can be attached to the head of the robot and each module can move two stepper motor independently (vertical movement and plunger of the syringe). There are electrical connections between the robot and the syringe module, therefore, you do not need to plug any wires to the syringe. Up to 11 modules can be attached at the same time. We built seven robots that are working in different universities around the world (Copenhagen, Bristol, Glasgow, Trento, Prague, Toronto and Karlsruhe).

This robot was designed as part of the Evobliss project, which was funded by the European Union. There are two repositories and one wiki with more information about how to use and build the robot:

  • Software repository
  • Hardware repository
  • Users Wiki

Check the robot in action!

Please, note that this robot needs some skills in order to build it: First, it needs customs printed circuit boards, You need to order them from a manufacturer and solder SMD components on them. Mechanical components are laser cut or 3D printed. Brass inserts are used to avoid tapping. You need also to crimp cables for the connectors of the motors.

Cite: Faina, A., Nejatimoharrami, F., Stoy, K., Theodosiou, P., Taylor, B., & Ieropoulos, I. (2016). EvoBot: An open-source, modular liquid handling robot for nurturing microbial fuel cells. In Artificial Life Conference 2016 (p. 626).

Design

The mechanical design was created in SolidWorks. The 3D printed parts are also exported as STL and the laser cut parts are exported as DXF and PDF. All the files are in the mechanical repository. If you need to modify the design and you do not have access to a SolidWorks license, you can upload the design to Onshape, which is a cloud based CAD program that can import native Solidworks files.

The electronic design was made in DesignSparkPCB, which is free to use. The PCB was exported to Gerber files and can be submitted to manufactures directly. All the designs are in the hardware repository.

Building instructions

The latest building instructions can be found in the EVOBLISS-HARDWARE repository (documentation\building instructions). A complete bill of materials (BOM) is also found there.
Below is only an overview of the assembly process.

Mechanics

The plates of the head and side carriages should be laser cut in POM (recommended) or PLA in 4mm.
The height control plates and the module parts should be laser cut in POM on 3mm.
The linear guides of the robot are made of V-slot aluminium profiles and rolling wheels. They can be found in several DIY shops like OpenBuilds or RatRig.
The 3D printed parts can be printed using a FDM printer or they can printed using SLS technology (nylon) in a 3D printing shop such us 3DprintUK or Sculpteo
We also used a lot brass inserts to avoid tapping. Some holes of the plates need to be countersunk, a 90 degrees countersinking tools and a drilling machine is needed.

Electronics

There are two different custom boards that need to be produced: head boards and module board. You need to order the PCBs and the components to assemble them.
The head board is used to share the electrical connections from the Arduino to the sockets of the modules. This board uses SMD components but it is easy to solder by hand. You only need two of this board per robot.
The module board is fixed on the back of the syringe modules and contains the stepper drivers that control the syringes. The stepper drivers have a fine pitch between their legs (0.65mm) and it could be difficult to solder by hand. We recommend you that you order an stencil and use a hot air soldering station. You need one of this boards per module.
If you do not have the skills needed to solder them, you can contact different manufactures. They can handle all the process (produce the PCBs and stencils, ordering the parts and solder them), but it can be very expensive. Try to use some of these shops: Smart-Prototyping or PCB-NG.

Finally an Arduino Mega 2560, a Ramps board and a few Pololu stepper drivers are also needed. Fortunately, they can be bought from almost any shop that sells hardware for 3D printers.

Software

You need to download the software from the software repository. Then, install the Arduino IDE and program the firmware of the Arduino. This process is described in our Wiki.

The control programs are written in Python and we have lots of examples. You can also used the API to write your programms. Everything is well documented in our Wiki.

Acknowledgements

The authors would like to thank E.U. Future and Emergent Technologies who supported this work through EVOBLISS grant no. 611640 and the members of the EVOBLISS consortium who provided input for the requirements and tested the robot.

Questions

Just send me an email

Enjoy it!
Andres

description.text:
MCS frames have hook holes relatively far from the frame edge. Unfortunately this means that the hook must be far down from the nail, or it rests on the nail itself.

Since I did not like to put just nails in the wall, and I wanted to use a hook, I made these long hooks which are suitable for MCS style poster frames. (You'll find them even in your local stores and online)

After buying several sets of hooks, and none of them really fit, I designed my own. They appear highly reliable and currently support 20+ frames at my place.

The hole to put the nail is slightly inclined, and the hole size is large enough for most nails and small enough for most nail heads.

Printing 1 hook may take up to 14 minutes individually, you should try one before you print a batch of 10 which make take over an hour and a half.

title: Adafruit Huzzah ESP8266 with 3.5" TFT Featherwing table top case

description.text:
I bought a ESP8266 Huzzah Feather and 3.5" LCD Featherwing from Adafruit and wanted a table top case to put them in. I designed the case just big enough so that the displayable area of the LCD is centered in the bezel. The top and bottom are also symmetrical so I can use the case with the cord on either the left or right and adjust the screen rotation in software.

This is a challenging print, I printed it with the back on the bed and the bezel face up and 0.1mm layer height is needed given the gentle slope of the bezel and to realize usable screw threads in the 8 holes. Because of the 0.1mm layer height I had to add an extra layer gap between the top of the support and the bottom of the model or else the support couldn't be removed cleanly. But I'm thrilled with the result.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

This is a challenging print, you need to have a well tuned machine to pull it off. The 0.1mm layer height is needed for the M3 screw threads and the finish on the front bezel. I printed it with the bezel facing up which also means the screw holes are vertical. With the 0.1mm layer height it can be tricky to print the support so it can be removed without destroying the print - I had to add an extra layer between the top of the support and the model. To hold it down to the bed I used a wide 2 layer brim.

The LCD is attached to the case with 4 M3x6mm hex cap screws and another 4 M3x6mm screws attach the back. A ball nose 2.5mm hex wrench is needed to tighten the screws that attach the LCD to the case since the wrench needs to go in at an angle to the screws.

title: Zelda - Breath of the Wild - Temple of Time

description.text:
Model of the Temple of the Time from The Legend of Zelda - Breath of the Wild

UPDATE 03/04/2018:

Ran a test print of the newest version to see how it would come out (see pictures). Printed it on a small scale (0.6) so details came out a little smudgy (plus my current printer has issues I can't for some reason figure out). Printed at .2mm detail with supports and brim and a 20% infill. Single material (PLA). Result was decent after a 14hr print at 40mm/s. Removing the supports was very hard, especially for the small rooms in the front of the temple. Getting the material out without damaging the stairs and bird statues was impossible. One small area on the sides of the entrance still does not print; I will have to use a shell modifier and upload a new version to fix. I HIGHLY recommend printing this with a dissolvable filament for support as it's almost a guarantee you will damage the print trying to remove them. Check back soon for an updated version. If you like my work, please consider sending me a tip via my profile page. As always, I appreciate the support!

UPDATE 02/24/2018:

author: Jbenedetto84

title: Friday 3d Printing Community Hangout ( F3DPCH ) Logo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the official logo of the Friday 3D Printing Community Hangout or F3DPCH for short.
Uploaded files are the following
1-part file is a single file including all the parts of the logo for single extrusion printing.
The files named with Color names are for easy multi-color prints. The files are to be imported into your slicer, then aligned by origin.
After designing these files, I proceeded to do the first test print @ 245% scale on the CR10S in 4 colors, pictured above.

What is F3DPCH?
Well the short story is, it is a stream hosted on different YouTube channels on a bi-weekly schedule. Each stream a YouTube channel hosts the stream, and picks a topic. Those topics have ranged from 3d printing tips and tricks, to troubleshooting, 3d printer maintenance, and 3d modeling software. We've also discussed things like selling 3d printed items, and even content creation. This helps spread exposure to channels big and small, and has created a great community that each week joins via video, or in the chat. For more information scoll to the bottom to see how you can follow when and where the stream will be hosted, and what the topic is for the week.
Long story:
About 1 year before the upload of these files, I (Matt - How I Do It) asked a random question on Twitter of who whould want to do a live hangout that evening. I was met with a response from Vicky Somma (TGAW3d), Heather (A Pyro Design & the 3D Pink Mafia), Lauren Angers (Abuzz Designs), and Tessa (SparkyFace5). We admittedly got of to a slow start, the second question I asked was how was the weather. But we started to get our footing and started discussing etsy, and 3d printing projects. At that time it was random, but the response after the stream was overwhelming. I got so many questions of whether we were going to do it again the following week. So there was enough interest, and we did. This was the start of F3DPCH. I hosted that second stream, then the third stream Travis (A Pyro Design) hosted on his channel. That was the start of the rotating channels hosting the stream. The co-host panel quickly grew to the point that in the 2nd and 3rd stream we overloaded the capabilities for hosts, and actually had a waiting line of hosts waiting to join. The topics mostly revolved around 3d printing, but then we started getting questions about content creation on youtube. A community began to grow, and the great thing was the exposure of changing hosting channels each week, allowed for people watching to learn of other content creators on youtube, and actually began helping smaller channels get subs, and bringing some new subs to the larger channels. We were streaming every Friday up until the summer, when peoples schedules got busy, and the weather was nicer, so we switched to bi-weekly streams. This allowed for the hosts to spend time with their families, and not take a commitment to every single Fiday night. Since then we've been going strong discussing 3d printing, youtube, events like makerfaires, selling 3d prints, 3d modeling software and more. We grew a large community of regulars, and each week we get some new viewers, and some weeks we get new hosts.
If you would like to follow the streams, and find out when and where the stream will be, below are links to the social media sites that we utilize to get the word out.
Twitter - https://www.twitter.com/F3DPCH
Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/groups/293906417686785/?ref=bookmarks
Email - [email protected]
If you would like to co-host or host a stream and pick the topic please communicate via one of these methods, and we will get you setup with how to do it.

I would like to personally thank Mike ( NLTMW ) for designing the logo for F3DPCH, in November 2017, we asked for community submissions of logos for the stream, which would then be voted on by the community for the official logo. Mike's logo you see here was selected. I then took Mike's design, and went into Fusion360 and designed the files you can download here on Thingiverse.

We hope to see you on the stream and in the chat, dont be afraid to post questions, we do our best to answer them. Let us know you found the stream through Thingivers, and tag photos of your print with @F3DPCH on twitter, or share on the 3d printing facebook groups, and in the F3DPCH facebook group.

title: Pythagoras, Pythagorean Theorem, 3D Models, 勾股定理, ピタゴラス定理

description.text:
Pythagoras, Pythagorean Theorem, 3D Models

The Pythagorean Theorem can be illustrated (not proved) using 3D models. In fact, it is a direct implication of a^2 + b^2 = c^2 in a 3D space. Pick an h > 0. Then, ha^2 + hb^2 = hc^2. We could construct a square-end box of a constant height along each side of the right triangle. However, there is much more to it. We could build infinitely many 3D (or 2D) models. As long as the three 3D solids (or corresponding 2D shapes) are similar to each other, the volume of the solid on the hypotenuse is equal to the sum of the volumes of the two solids on the two legs. Some 3D models are aesthetically attractive; others are not so much.

Included here are three 3D models on a right triangle that is 30mm, 50mm, and sqrt(3400)mm—semi-circle, square, and trapezoid. They all have a depth of 30mm. You can use water, sand, or rice to demonstrate the relationships. It is a bit messy and is also fun for students!

description.text:
Just a set of seven propellers with the blade angles changed from 0 to 90 in 15 degree steps.
Used for a Physics project in order to see how the angle of the blade affected the lift.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

Most of these can be printed flat but I found that once the blade angle reached 60 it was necessary to print them vertically with a lot of support.
Some gentle sanding is required to smooth out any support residue
NGSS

Overview

As part of a Higher Level Physics IB project a student wanted to investigate how the angle of a propeller blade affected the lift.
The propellers were designed in Fusion 360 and the blade angle altered from 0 to 90 degrees in 15 degree steps.

Method

The propellers were printed out in PLA at 65% scale in order to fit the motor axle that we were using.

Each blade is attached to the motor which is then mounted on an electronic balance.

If the blade is mounted 'upside-down', as the propeller rotates it pushes down onto the balance. The resultant measurement can be converted to a force using F=mg.

A graph of Force vs Angle can then be produced.

An interesting extension is to devise a method to measure the speed of the rotation and repeat the experiment at different speeds. One of the more creative solutions to this was to attach a small piece of paper to one end of a blade. As it rotates, the paper hits against a microphone and the frequency of the registered 'taps' was analysed using Audacity.

Likewise the experiment could be carried out as a "Wind Turbine" investigation and e.m.f. induced measured from the motor.

Safety Note: A safety screen was used when carrying out this experiment as some of the propellers had sharp edges

Equipment

7 printed propellers
d.c. motor
electronic balance
variable power supply
safety screen

comments.text: Nice setup! Which angle had the best lift? Was it enough to lift the motor?

"To the righteous we bring hope. To the tainted we bring fire."
— Castellan Garran Crowe
Castellan Garran Crowe, warden of the Blade of Antwyr

Garran Crowe is a Castellan of the Grey Knights Space Marine Chapter and a notable hero of that elite unit of Astartes. Castellan Crowe is both head and Brotherhood Champion of the Purifier Order. A nobler exemplar of the Grey Knights would be impossible to find -– by the measure of the Grey Knights, Crowe is a flawless soul, not so much resistant to the temptations of Chaos as immune to them. It is well that this is so, for Garran bears a burden greater than any of his brothers: the Blade of Antwyr, a cursed relic of unimaginable evil that continuously brings him into both physical and spiritual peril by tempting him with Chaotic promises of power or seeking to bind his will with black sorcery. Even so, Crowe must be forever on guard, for the sword's sibilant whispers echo endlessly through his mind, offering to add its strength to his own in the pursuit of victory. Many men would embrace such a chance, thinking their will would be strong enough to control the sword. Yet no matter how dark the hour or desperate the battle, Crowe has never succumbed; his thoughts and actions are his own. He is the warden of the blade, incorruptible and inviolable, and will remain so until the day of his death. Some of the Grand Masters believe that Crowe embodies a dormant strain of the Chapter's gene-seed, a piece of the Emperor that has awoken and taken root within him. It is this quality that grants Crowe a unique perspective on the world, as he does not see Chaos as others do. To Crowe, the Immaterium is as water flowing over reality, cool and deep, with Daemons flitting like shadows beneath its surface.

title: Seattle Seahawks Ornament, Keychain, and Magnet

description.text:
These logos are optimized for 3 or 4 colors and hot swapping during printing. The layer color order and thickness is:

  1. White - thickness varies
  2. Silver - 0.8mm thick (x4 0.2mm layers)
  3. Green - 0.8mm thick (x4 0.2mm layers)
  4. Blue - 0.8mm thick (x4 0.2mm layers)

I had trouble with the green top fill layers with only the eye green, so I printed one with the eye and under the eye area green with better quality results. Both are uploaded to see if you have better luck. I sliced in Cura, then reviewed the layers to figure out when to pause the print. Pause the print as soon as you are on the bottom of the 0.8mm thickness of each color, and I recommend setting top layer thickness to 0.8 so that each of the top 3 color layers are 100% fill.

description.text:
This is a fully 3D printed symmetrical butterfly knife modeled after a Benchmade Model 42 as reference.

Be sure to know your printers tolerance settings as the model accounts for ZERO TOLERANCE between the pins and the model. I suggest you scale down the pins to 98 or 99% of the original model size before printing. You may need more or less depending on your printer.

In order for it to flip smoothly, you will likely need to lubricate the plastic pins and "Break in" your butterfly knife by rapidly moving the handles. Do this until the blade flips to your expectation.

Included is the Fusion 360 File that also shows the joinery. The CAD file is built with bad practices, and I apologize if you dislike the construction because of it.

Steps
  1. Clean supports
  2. Arrange the LED Bar
  3. Put foarm on both sides to damp vibrations and make bar tight (Optional but great)
  4. Put bar in the brackets and place it on Prusa Z Axis, not screw yet
  5. Verify distance and holes, if all match without bent or force X axis go to step 6.
    5.1 If not aligned means bar is oversizing, cut a bit of plastic from the left side as i did (The screw holder on bar is useless, cut that)
  6. Take it back and align cable and zip-tie it
  7. Double check everything and screw it on the printer
  8. Push led bar right and left to release and remove pressure from brackets, make sure they are perfect aligned and not forcing Z Axis
  9. Enjoy great ilumination!

I have remixed this parts, all i have done is import to Windows 3D Builder, place original parts over the bracket, ajust the rods holes and it's done. Some flaws are visible to the computer but after print it come out perfect.

title: 28mm miniature Boat Tiles PART 2: Raised Decks

description.text:
This is an expansion for my set of tiles for creating custom miniature sailing ships for tabletop roleplaying. The original set [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2380515] is still required. What this set adds is the option of having decks at multiple elevations, for your forecastle and sterncastle.

Q: How do these go together exactly?
A: Most of these pieces have connections at the top and the bottom. The "support" piece is used to hold a regular piece from the old set up at the new height (so you can have your helm or your sterncastle etc.), and these will snap into the top slots on the other pieces. The inner wall, door, and stair pieces just clip into the top slots and dangle over the lower deck. Hopefully between the third picture and this description you can make sense of it. If not, comment about it and I can try to get better pictures.

Q: Why do some of the models have "A" at the end?
A: So I made this cool mostly-hollow design for the interiors of the ships, but then I realized that it's actually less time and filament to just make them all one solid block and print with 5% infill. So you should use the "A" models. I only kept the old ones in case you want to have something stored inside your ship (have a cannon or something leaning out the windows?).

Q: Why didn't you use OpenLock?
A: 'Cause I was young and foolish when I started, and I'm old and foolish now. A hero named Haratu remixed my original set to use OpenLock [https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2460693]. Who knows, maybe they'll do it again.

Q: Those cannons are rad.
A: Not mine. You can find those here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2160741

Q: Those sailor minis are pretty cool too.
A: Ok, usually I'd just go "they're from Old Glory," but I'ma link you to this specific set (yeah, they're all one set) 'cause they're awesome: http://www.oldgloryminiatures.com/proddetail.asp?prod=OGP-14

print_settings.Notes:: The model is threaded to match the flashlight's tube, so I would suggest a layer height of 0.1mm to print clean threads.

title: Threaded Flashlight Tube Extension To Fit A 18650 Battery (25mm tube)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple tube extension for an inexpensive type of LED flashlight. The flashlight normally takes three AAA batteries that are held in a caddy, These AAA caddies are often used to replace an 18650 battery, so it seemed like a good idea to do the reverse. Of course the big gain in battery capacity is a side bonus. :-)

Ideally this extension would be printed in one of the new conductive plastics since the metal tube of the flashlight is the ground return. I don't have any of that plastic, so the model has a hole through it to place a piece of wire to make the contacts. I've since tried using copper foil tape to make the connection, and while this has worked well, the wire method will last longer. See the post-printing instructions for both options.

This extension is made for a flashlight with an approximately 25mm diameter tube with a thread spacing of 1mm.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-17

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

The model is threaded to match the flashlight's tube, so I would suggest a layer height of 0.1mm to print clean threads.

The inexpensive flashlight and AAA battery caddy. Using Wire as the Conductor

The extension model has a hole that will fit ~20 gauge wire. I found it to be easier to start by screwing on the cap end, so I'd suggest starting there. The difficult part is holding the wire in place while screwing the cap onto the extension.

Once the cap is in place, have a look up inside the extension to ensure the wire was pressed into the groove by the threads, and wasn't simply pushed out of the way. I only had this problem with the cap end, but the result is an unreliable connection and a flickering flashlight.

If the wire is correctly seated, place your 18650 battery into the flashlight (positive end towards the front) and screw the extension onto the body.

Copper Foil

I recently tried using copper foil tape to make the connection. It works well, although the metal threads do wear through it. I wrapped the copper foil tape around the inside and outside of the extension and then screwed the parts together. (Don't worry - there's no electrocution risk. It's the same as how the flashlight uses the metal body as the ground return.) This seems to work well, but it won't last as long as the wire method -- the metal threads (especially the cap threads) quickly wear into the copper foil.

The flashlight with the extension tube and copper foil.

description.text:
This is a motorcycle phone mount for the iPhone 7, specifically designed for my iPhone 7 that has a Griffin Survivor case on it. This is a very specific design for my case, but you could perhaps adapt it by adding some padding (weatherstrip tape) to the inside of the mount case to adapt other phones without changing the design. The mounting bracket is also designed to fit a 2016 Honda Africa Twin.

To assemble use 3x M4x30 stainless steel bolts, washers and nuts to go with it. To mount the case to the base mounts use 4x M4x15 s/s countersunk screws with washers and nuts. Nylock nuts or some threadlock are recommended for all.

To mount it I used zip ties, I made the mount slightly oversize so accommodate some padding material between the handlebars and the mount. A piece of inner tube rubber will work perfectly or in my case all I had was weatherstrip tape.

I printed this in PLA as a prototype but this will absolutely not withstand heat and/or direct sunlight. I will experiment with PETG and ABS soon.

I will also at some stage make different versions for different phones and mounts for different bikes. I also want to design a mounting system that uses nuts and bolts instead of zip ties.

Heavily inspired by McNugget's design: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1433266

EDIT

I have added mounts for the BMW F800GS. They use 4x M4x30 cap head screws. Works really well, will adapt the Africa Twin mounts to also use screws and bolts.

title: Drawer Front Clip - Fabritec Base Cabinet Drawer (0317)

description.text:
I designed this Drawer Front Clip for a Fabritec kitchen drawer, after moving into my new place last year. One was broken and after some procrastination I decided to design and print one!

This clip is screwed into the front faceplate of the kitchen drawer and allows you to clip the rest of the drawer assembly. "Fabritec - Base Cabinet Drawer (0317)" is where I found a manual that contained the clip.

I designed it on 123D Design and sliced it with Cura 2.1.3. It was then printed on a Monoprice Maker Select v2.

The uploaded pictures show the final version (green), a first draft (red) and the OEM part (white).

Here's a link to a Youtube video where I recorded the design process. It starts out with a quick Instagram video of the finished product and 3D file, then goes into a 7 minute timelapse of the design process. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rMLsaLUxyVw

Fabritec Base Cabinet Drawer (0317) Manual - http://www.cuisine-eurostyle.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/PLAN-0317.pdf

description.text:
Cheap Disposable Spray Booth ...

Designed to be made from small sheets of cardboard.
Can be easily cut out & assembled by hand.

Enjoy, Bantum ... :)

Hand drawn / cut out prototype.

Drawn up in AutoCAD / Sketchup.

CDR files for Laser Cutting ...

Hardware :

Basic list ...

  • Cardboard : 700 x 440 mm Sheet ( 7 of )
  • Mesh : Aldi 500 x 300 mm BBQ Grill
  • Filter : Insulation Batt ( Disposable Filter can be used )
  • LED light : Any common type ( Type Used ... TBA )
  • Fan : ( TBA ) Variety of fans can be used ...
Consumables :

  • Paints : Variety of Aerosol paints can be used ...
    ( Make sure to use responsibly )

  • Filter : Type TBA ... ( used insulating batts )
Notes :

  • Layout has been optimized to fit on a sheet of cardboard ... ( to fit in laser cutter )

  • Fan used in the prototype was an old 250mm ceiling exhaust fan I had lying around ...
    ( Probably better flow options out there, just need something with enough draw )

  • Investigating the use of a Centrifugal fan ... ( TBA )

  • LED lights ... ( more info to add )

Assembly :

Gather parts / tools on a large bench space, Layout & cut-out the pieces as you go ...

Assemble booth in following order ...

  • Fan Box to Base ...
  • Sides to Base ...
  • Top to Fan Box / Sides ...

Install your selected fan in box ...

  • Fan Cover to Box ...
  • Duct to Cover ...
  • Locate Filter in Booth ...

Install LED & Ductwork as required ...

Operation :

  • Make sure to clear sufficient work space from hazardous materials ...

  • Ensure vent goes to outside clear ...

  • Secure work to enable free hand operation ...

More to come ...

Tools :

Some basic tools required to assemble it ...

  • Sharp knife
  • Ruler
  • Packing Tape
  • Hot glue ( not necessary )

This is a work in progress, will be updated when I've got more to add.

Edits :
  • Revised notes & added few more details ...
  • Added .cdr files for laser cutting ...
Just a simple phone stand I use at work to leave my phone on.

C&C Red Alert radar dome.
This model was sculpted in Creo Elements using RA screen shots as a guide.

I don’t know how many of you have a microphone like this, or more specifically the stand that it uses… But i’ve found the factory stand to be quite large and intrusive. So I’ve made a smaller simpler base for the stand.

There’s a simple model "Micstand Simple", then there’s one where I went crazy with holes and the fillet feature "Micstand Alt" :)

You just need to unscrew and remove the base factory stand and place the new one on. It’s designed to be used without a fastener.
Micstand Alt Micstand Simple Original/ replaced micstand
Anyone who has looked at the head model in detail might have noticed it is a little messed up. I did my best to remove the holes and push back the weird stretches.

author: BrandonPcGuy

description.text:
Hi there,

I just waned to build a bigger locomotive from Lego Duplo together with my two children.

In case of that, the overhang gets to big and you got a lot of other problems.

Due to that I started the construction of an own locomotive. The Result is the uploaded steam-train. A standard Lego - Duplo train runs about 750 m/h this one is calculated for a speed of 1000 m/h so it is 25% faster. It will be started and stopped by remote control.
It should accelerate and decelerate very soft.

Due to some problems with my printer, I am not ready with printing this Project.

Might be I will modify some parts later, but it should be nearly perfect.

If you have questions, remarks or suggestions please contact me.

There were several mistakes in the file names:

  1. I did not translate everything, sorry:

       Boden = Floor

   Rad = Wheel

   Kessel = Boiler

  2. While uploading the braces were deleted:

       Kessel _12x = Kessel_1(2x)

The Trims (Wheel connectors) and Rear Cover are under construction.
So it will be uploaded soon.

Printer:

MeCreator 2

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.2 Nozzle 0.05 Layer

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I Print PLA with 195°C

For thin sectors use a good cooling. (Sample: Wheels 4 steps of cooling)

For a higher cooling rate I installed a thicker fan 12V fan in my 24V printer;
so I can step up the fan speed. I got perfect results.
By the way I use a self constructed Ring duct.

Only small strings appear.

For a perfect result I print on a glass plate with 70°C.

!!!! ATTENTION !!!!

Keep the glass plate at 70°C until the Print is finished.
After printing: Wait until the glass is cooled down.
So you were able to remove the Parts without any force.

Ball Bearings 4 x ball bearing 6801 / 61801 ZZ / 12 x 21 x 5 mm https://www.ebay.de/itm/4-Kugellager-6801-61801-ZZ-12-x-21-x-5-mm/262641161027?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649 16 x ball bearing 686 6x13x5 https://www.ebay.de/itm/20-Kugellager-686-ZZ-6-x-13-x-5-mm/251354798992?hash=item3a85e9db90:g:wr4AAOSwNSxU4cT0 2 x for joints I will describe later which one I choosed. Powertrain 4 x transmission motor https://www.ebay.de/itm/60-RPM-6V-0-3A-Hohes-Drehmoment-Mini-Elektrischer-DC-Getriebemotor-fuer-Rob-G8Y3/182741123156?hash=item2a8c384054:g:cm8AAOSwaOxZp8Pb Resistors, LEDs, Capacitors & Wires Resistor - set https://www.ebay.de/itm/Widerstands-Sortiment-mit-480-Bauteilen-1-4W-E3-10-Ohm-bis-1-MOhm-Set/281434487881?hash=item4186cd7c49:g:ZckAAOSw7NNUDcek LED - set https://www.ebay.de/itm/3mm-5mm-LED-Sortiment-200-Stuck-rot-grun-gelb-blau-weis-Leuchtdioden-Superhelle/152253219785?hash=item2372ffc3c9:g:tRUAAOSwUKxYlZXl 2 x Capacitor (gold cab) for soft Start/Stop I will describe later which one I choosed. 2 x Diode to slow down the voltage at capacitor. Wires should be thin...
feel free Voltage Step up 1 x Voltage step up (vor adusting the speed) Style 4 https://www.ebay.de/itm/LTC1871-Booster-Step-Up-Module-DC-3-5-35V-Converter-Regulated-Power-Supply-100W/182327243280?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649 Expendables 1 x Superglue https://www.ebay.de/itm/Sekundenkleber-10-Gramm-Flasche-Pinsel-Super-Glue-Extra-Stark-Kraftkleber-4425/371536843272?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649 24 x Screws and nuts. I will describe later which one I choose. Also some acetone might be helpfull. Remote Control I will use the Remote control unit of an old Power socket. for application a 5v relay required. Accumulator 4 x Accumulator https://www.ebay.de/itm/4x-PolarCell-Mono-D-HR20-Premium-Akku-Ni-MH-Accus-aufladbare-Batterien-Ackus/390112844070?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2055119.m1438.l2649 Charger 1 x Charger https://www.ebay.de/itm/XTAR-Ladegeraet-VC4-Li-Ion-Ni-MH-LCD-Charger-/292430073887? Springs and screws for battery case 2 x Hex socket head screws M3 x 20 2 x springs for fixation and connection to accumulators. I will describe later which one I choose.

description.text:
This is a close copy of the replacement booster ring holder that was provided due to the rocket ships breaking. The publisher has run out of replacement rings and thus anyone who buys the game second hand or even new will not be able to get them, unless the previous owner had them, or the new copy was a later printing, with rings supplied.

There are other basic designs on thingiverse, but they required too much filing and sanding to get right. I believe my design fits on snuggly and holds the boosters without being too tight and hard to remove. Plus its a close-ish copy to the official rings. and actually cover up the clips on the rocket for the boosters, thus preventing those from breaking.

Update: Simplify3D was picking up that the decorative dots were not correctly melded to the model. This has been fixed. Cura did not have this issue.

Printer:

Cocoon Create Model Maker

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

I have printed early prototypes upside down without supports successfully, but the current design may not work due to the decorative dots.

comments.text: The decorative dots are not properly welded into the model.  Simplify3D (and possibly other slicers) treats each one as its own inset model.  I printed these at 0.1mm with a 0.25mm nozzle and every single dot fell out of the print.  Looking at it closer in Meshmixer revealed the issue.  I'll try to attach the fixed stl to this post.  Excellent model regardless and thank you for submitting it.  =)

print_settings.Notes:: Printing using ZYLtech PETG. 230 degrees on the hot end and 85 on the bed. I am using the Volcano hot end with a .6mm tip so that is why I am at .350 layer height. If using a standard .4mm print these parts at .2mm resolution. I printed as the parts are laid out here. If you print in the same orientation add supports under the corner part when you print them. I recommend a 10 lap skirt as well, keeping it around .25mm from the part so it holds everything in place. For the tubes I used the same settings but went with 25 laps on the skirt. Keep the feed down to 40mm/sec for the tubes. If you shorten the tubes you could print a lot faster. But you'd be printing more parts.

title: ANY 3D PRINTER FULLY PRINTABLE ENCLOSURE FRAME

description.text:
I am designing this enclosure to house my Creality CR-10, but this can be easily modified to house any 3d printer or other machine. There are views in the photos here that show the parts in their intended orientation with info about that view of the assembly. I have included the parts I am printing for my CR-10 which are the files labeled "PART_NAME_MAKE_X". The other file with all the components together can be used to modify this to fit your needs.

I will be adding to this and this will eventually include the door assembly with hinges, cable management options, and a drawer slide assembly so the machine can slide out for maintenance. I will also be releasing a version 2 which will contain a lower set of compartments to house the control and some drawers for tools and such. Stay tuned and follow if you wish to receive updates.

Update 2-3-18: Rearranging the orientation to print the tubes vertically. Having them laid on the bed did not work out too well. But they print beautifully vertical. See print settings for info.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.35

Infill:

100% on tubes, 20% on corners

Notes:

Printing using ZYLtech PETG. 230 degrees on the hot end and 85 on the bed. I am using the Volcano hot end with a .6mm tip so that is why I am at .350 layer height. If using a standard .4mm print these parts at .2mm resolution. I printed as the parts are laid out here. If you print in the same orientation add supports under the corner part when you print them. I recommend a 10 lap skirt as well, keeping it around .25mm from the part so it holds everything in place. For the tubes I used the same settings but went with 25 laps on the skirt. Keep the feed down to 40mm/sec for the tubes. If you shorten the tubes you could print a lot faster. But you'd be printing more parts.

I was finally asked to make my first model for cosplay. A set of 6 daggers for a V / Guy Fawkes costume of V for Vendetta fame. They wanted plastic as the metal replicas are not con friendly. I will post more pictures after they have painted and finished them.

At 150mm x 150mm x 150mm I have a relatively small volume printer (printrbot simple metal) I mistakenly thought it would limit my ability to create but it only made me more creative.

I modeled it off of pictures off of the internet and I am sorry that the wrap around the handle doesn't look like a chain.

I have uploaded the dagger three different ways.

  1. For small volume printers, the model is split into 5 parts and needs 3 keys

  2. For large volume printers, the model is split into 2 parts and needs one key

  3. The whole 18" one piece model

All parts are in the correct orientation for printing. I printed with 4** outer layers and 15 - 20% infill

The key is just a "+" shaped part that fits in between the parts to help with assembly.

Post processing - I used hot glue on one and super glue on another but I also used a wood burner at the seams to weld them smooth/closed. This is why I recommend 4 outer layers/parameters I am pleased with how strong it is.

**This might help someone... If your slicer askes for parameters or outer layers the answer is probably 4 but on other slicers, it might ask for shell thickness (mm) and you will have to do some math. example my nozzle is .5mm so if I want 4 outer layers the math is .5 x 4 = 2mm wall thickness. If your nozzle is .4mm the math would be .4 x 4 = 1.6mm wall thickness.

Consider supporting me by following, stabbing the button to like or donate, or maybe buying yourself something nice on Amazon. By using my affiliate link I get a kickback at no extra cost to you! http://amzn.to/2GwOvL1

Thanks for looking!
