title: X ends and related parts for 8mm leadscrews, for vanilla Prusa i3 (singleplate)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a remix of Whitehawk2000's X ends for leadscrews on the Prusa i3.

I've altered the parts as follows:

  • 13 mm hole center hole for the leadscrew coupler, to make room for the anti-backlash spring
  • X idler pulley holder has a cut to make room for the anti-backlash coupler's endcap, and it now accepts Prusa's standard 623ZZ-based "belt guide" (i.e. the vanilla singleplate model)
  • Re-cut bolt/nut holes in the idler pulley holder and thumb wheel to accept M5 hex bolts (because those are all I have with hex heads :-P )
  • Added an M5 nut trap to the idler pulley holder
  • Increased the in-model diameter of the smooth rods' holes in the X ends to about 8.3mm, to account for normal shrinkage and quantization errors that always happen with horizontal holes.
  • Added support columns to the X ends, one set of which is intended to be broken off (the idler end), so that slicer-provided support material isn't needed

This only includes the "backward" version of the X motor mount, since that's what matches my bot.

Like the parts I remixed these from, these have the linear rods set 17 mm from the leadscrews (center-to-center).

Also included are some washers in 1, 2, 4, and 8 mm thicknesses, to accommodate different M5 tensioning bolt lengths. Stack them just behind the thumbwheel as needed.

If you find that your X rods are too short to poke out of the X idler end (as mine were, because they're standard i3 length), drill a ~3.5 - 3.8 mm hole through each end of the tensioner end piece, to allow you to drive in a pair of M4 screws long enough to reach the X rods' ends (let the screws cut their own threads).

After printing, you may still need to ream the X rods' holes out with an 8 mm drill (you need to get the rods to slide in without a bunch of effort).

After mounting one of the couplers, go ahead and put your linear bearings into their holder, add the spring and anti-backlash cap to the coupler, and add in your linear rod and lead screw, and check that the screw wants to stay parallel to the rod. If they aren't, add an M3 washer to one of the coupler's mounting screws, between the coupler and the X endpiece, to correct it as needed.

Once you're sure they're parallel, do the other side, then assemble the X ends, X rods, and leadscrews and hold the assembly up with X parallel to the floor, allowing the leadscrews to dangle. Make sure the lead screws appear to be at right angles to the X rods.

Once everything's square, clamp the linear bearings into their holders, go ahead and put your printer back together, re-calibrate your Z steps/mm and starting Z height, and give it a whirl.

Vitamins:
3, M3 x 8 mm screws (to mount the motor... I think, I need to double check what I used)
8, M3 x 12-14 mm screws (to mount the couplers, and for the linear bearing clamps)
1, M3 x 20 mm screw (for the idler pulley)
2, M4 x 30-40 mm screws (optional)
1, M5 x 30-35 mm screw with hex head (main idler tension screw)
2, M3 washers (optional)
9, M3 nuts (one nylock, for the idler pulley)
1, M5 nut
1, 623ZZ bearing (idler pulley)

Update 2018-02-09: Increased the clearance around the spring and anti-backlash cap, and for your convenience, I've copied over bernbout's 5mm-to-8mm self centering motor-to-leadscrew coupler, with nuts, taken from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1651349 .

Update 2018-02-06: Minor rework of the "support columns" on the idler end - they're a bit thicker and have a connecting bridge between them to help avoid them being knocked over while they're printing, and I've redone the deliberate weak spots (in the thickest parts) to make it easier to break them off when the part is finished. I also added narrow cuts to both idler ends, similar to what I did on the idler pulley holder, to make sure your slicer has a good place to put the seams when it goes to do the overhanging bits near the tops. I've thickened the walls of the idler pulley holder very slightly to make it slice cleaner.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

No

No

40-60%

Notes:

author: VanessaE

description.text:
Added a coil winder head that fit an M3 screw to hold coil cores

Update...
As I used it with a little spool of wire it was not very stable, so I added some blocks to fix the THING to a board of plywood or something heavy enough to hold it still while winding...

This is a simple coil winder with a holder for the main magnet wire spool.
The coil holder is desiged to fit the coils I make, but it is held by 4 screws ad can be replaced with a different holders in a minute.
It has a camme where a microswitch (the ones found on 3d printers) is installed for turns counting and a plate where I glued a calculator modified to be a counter.
To build it I used 1mt long M5 threaded rod and some M5 nuts and washers, and 2 bearings 5x16x5mm for the turning axle. You can add bearings on the spool holder axles if you like, I prefer just an alu tube without bearings because it gives a bit of friction to hold the wire in tension.
The axis holes in the parts that fit on the coil winder axle are shaped for M5 nuts so when everything is tightened, there is no need of set screws, everything turns as a whole.
The width of the assembly depends solely on the length of the threaded rods.

2 pcs of "Spalla.stl"
2 pcs of "Spalla interna.stl"
4pcs of "Spessori.stl"
The rest is one piece each.

comments.text: Ah yes, this brings back memories of my coil winding from years ago (the early 80s), setup the calculator 1+1, hook the switch to = and away you go, instant counter only limited by how many digits you have!!!!

title: Recycle-Fountain pen holder from scrap Pla- Recycle

description.text: I have used scrap Pla (Grey and beige) that I melted into a square, bottomless metallic form with backing sheet (non-stick paper) underneath. I broke the plastic as small as I can and put it in the oven to 240 C (460 F) until the plastic was melted evenly. Take it off the oven and after 1 or 2 minutes I pressed firmly the pens and the ink bottle to imprint them in plastic. Be careful that Lamy pens are made also from plastic and they could be deformed from the heat. Push and pull after 1-2 seconds.

remixed_from.author: condac
remixed_from.title: Geared bowden extruder for mk8 and flexible filament

description.text:
I didn't want to wait for bearings to post out and wanted to use the hardware that I had laying around, but like this design and so modified it to suit.

This is the same as the original, except for the filament path beaks being easier to print, (removable) now using 608 bearings throughout instead of the 625zz, using a standard m8 hobbed bolt, and having the filament path altered slightly to suit the new specs.

Still for 1.75mm filament with ptfe tube fed right up to the hobbed bolt and trimmed flush with the beak profile on the output side.

I also got lazy when remaking the filament clamp, it now screws down with a couple of m3x15 screws threaded directly into the plastic; its not ideal, and I had some self tappers in the scrap parts bin....

Print the body with supports and pause the print at no higher than 17.7mm (17.5 is better) to insert a segment of ptfe to act as a support for the upper beak. (only necessary if you're printing the one without the replaceable beak)

when using the replaceable beak, install the beak and the hobbed bolt before adding the top bearing housing so that the hobbed bolt can tilt slightly to avoid damaging the beak.
The beak is also slightly larger (too close) so that it touches the hob, this is so you can turn the hobbed bolt, grinding away the beak slightly so as to make a perfect fit with no gaps whatsoever.

Retains the gears from the original, just modded for a normal hobbed bolt, or design your own for a custom reduction ratio.

made a bearing spacer for behind the spur gear, .fcd file attached so you can edit the height to suite your hobbed bolt.

Edit; the "v2" files are further modified to make the ptfe tube fit better and so that the beak part restrains the filament even better and is removable/retained with a m3x17mm screw (17x2.85x0.5) so that the beak can be printed in a more optimal orientation; It will now print much better and do so without supports, when oriented as in the "plated v2" file)

Now the only part that requires supports is the extruder main body.

author: Skip_

description.text:
M25-at-layer-postprocessor
The .sh gets invoked from the slic3r post-processing scripts field.
The .pl is invoked as a terminal (so you can type into it) by the .sh
Just put them both in the same folder and invoke the .sh from Slic3r.

  • In slic3r's preview, determine at what Z value heights you need an M25 pause, to insert nuts or whatever, and remember those digits.
  • Export the file to gcode, or send to octoprint, and the post porocessing script will kick in, offering you a terminal to enter the Z values.
  • Enter them separated by carriage returns (hit enter), then hit enter by itself to finish.
  • If nothing failed you will now have a gcode file that has M25 pauses inserted as instructed.

Be aware that I use Octoprint's event handlers to add the necessary wrangling after the pause, and before the print resumes. (Hence the octoprint gcode screenshot). Failure to do these things usually means a failed print if (when) you bump the bed during the pause.
You could actually write them directly into my very amateur perl script, on either side of the M25 statement, but that's not my preference.

No, I'm not a perl coder. I re-learned enough to write this script this afternoon. It's probably not great.
Yes I wrote this for linux.
No I'm not going to try to guess why it might not work on other OSes.
Yes, you should comment/link here if you do.

updated the .pl with less dumb

description.text:
Build this unique, cool interactive free-standing LED Sphere with multiple sensors that can be used to provide a fun platform for further development - interaction, lighting or games.

The unit is 3D printed and uses an Arduino Nano, Gyro Board, Audio Mic sensors controlling 130 independently controlled colored LEDs. There are two buttons for adding effects and menus for this unique gadget - the possibilities for effects can be endless.

The build information can be found on Instructables here https://www.instructables.com/id/LED-Gyro-Sphere-Arduino/

A video clip of it in action can be seen here https://youtu.be/zW8bWbHkKJ4

https://youtu.be/pfBlFxLEX9k

The current code provided uses the Gyro output to change the color based on the rotation or attitude of the sphere which gives a unique effect as seen in the Youtube clip. I am progressively releasing example effects over the next few days that can be accessed through menus and displayed on the LED Gyro Sphere.

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

C2 R2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The Sphere is 110mm in diameter with a wall thickness of approx 3mm using Black PLA filament. There are 130 LEDs to connect within the unit so it was more practical to print the unit in four components to make it easier to access the inside of the sphere with a soldering iron.

I used a Robo C2 printer which performed well for the print. By splitting the build into 4 units and printing two small pieces at the same time reduces the print time significantly.

I have numbered the 4 individual items to print 1 - 4 and provided them as STL files.

Build Log:
10/2/2018: Updated parts with correct heights and corrected model splitting properly in Slic3r. Shortened file names for easier viewing in Thingiverse.
06/02/2018: All the parts have now been uploaded with the correct tolerances. Happy printing. :) As always just ping me if you have any issues or need a different size.
2/3/2018: Noticed an issue in the thread of the model. My mirrored parts have the opposite thread! Not an issue if you match the sides up correctly but still strange enough I want to fix. The test print has this issue. Revising the design slightly to have a beeter fit. Its tight in PLA so think ABS might be an issue with shrinkage. Anyone care to test?
1/2/2018: Looking for help: I need some to print a test of the 2 test parts to see if they fit together properly using another 3D printer. If someone can test and post a pic and pass comments that would be great. Print "Test Fit.stl" and see if it screws together properly. DONE!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iGKDOs6fW4Y

This is a remix of my last model with some improvements. The plan is to provide versions for 3,4,5 & 6mm plexiglass as many of you have requested this. I also plan on increasing the internal floor space slightly bringing the glass closer to the edge. In addition I'm redesigning the leg extensions so they can be printed as a separate parts should you wish to re-use/change these in the future. I'll be looking for some test printers if anyone is interested.

Various Options:
1 - Back legs are a duplicate of each other
2 - Front legs have 3 options.
A - Slots for perspex that is removable
B - Backstops for a potential swing door
C - Blank for space at the front (potential other door option)

File Format - "Total Internal Height" x "Perspex Thickness".stl
Note: You don't need to use or print the extentions. If you dont the total internal clearance will be 460mm.

Total Internal Clearance - This will be the final internal height once you put all the parts together.
Perspex Thickness - This is the thickness of the perspex that can be used with the stl.

For instructions on how to assemble please check out version 1. Most of this should be the same apart from the new screw in leg extentions. Have fun!

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2212749

Splitting Up the Models For Printing:

Slic3r https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52DU7ZSRmR0&t=47s
Simplify 3D (40 seconds in to the video) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1V-5aA03dQ&t=60s

title: Autolevel with Inductive Sensor P3 Steel

description.text:
Autoleveling is possible with an inductive sensor (LJ8A3-2-Z/BX-5V diameter: 8 mm). But thisinductive sensor needs a metal surface at 2 mm distance so I changed the glass printer bed (4 mm) with a custom made aluminium plate of 3 mm in thickness (dimensions are on the image). This sensor is NPN NO so it does not need any resistor or divider so it works with 5 volts. I have connected the wires directly to the z-axis endstop pins of the ramps board (Brown to Pin1, Blue to Pin2, Black to Pin3).
checkout my nozzle fan duct: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2771787
Bowden upgrade: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2766928
